metadata.description: 《动手学深度学习》：面向中文读者、能运行、可讨论。中英文版被70多个国家的500多所大学用于教学。

Initiated evaluation from scratch: 
http://ci.d2l.ai/blue/organizations/jenkins/d2l-zh/detail/PR-1198/1/pipeline

Check the results at http://preview.d2l.ai/d2l-zh/PR-1198/

> LGTM

![Screen Shot 2022-08-27 at 4 28 26 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22279212/187051392-f6e06959-c590-48cb-bcda-b1779f03c4b0.png)

Per http://ci.d2l.ai/blue/organizations/jenkins/d2l-zh/detail/PR-1198/3/pipeline/, it looks that the paddle evaluation runs significantly longer (1h47m) than implementation with other frameworks (pytorch 38m). Could you look into the complete log (click "Show Complete Log") and identify individual notebooks that take longer to evaluate? Can you improve the efficiency? 

For example:

1. why is there this error:

![Screen Shot 2022-08-27 at 4 31 31 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22279212/187051458-84cdc9dc-2ada-4db9-8fe0-64a9becd7f20.png)

2. In paddle complete log:
```
[d2lbook:resource.py:L223] INFO   Task "Evaluating ./chapter_computer-vision/image-augmentation.md" on CPU [1], GPU [1, 0] is finished in 00:12:19
```

In pytorch complete log:
```
[d2lbook:resource.py:L223] INFO   Task "Evaluating ./chapter_computer-vision/image-augmentation.md" on CPU [3], GPU [1, 3] is finished in 00:02:36
```

There can be more examples like the above.

hi @AnirudhDagar  I submitted the PR according to the provided process, the first PR is used to test process. The second is for committing chap3 content, and the third removes some "None" characters that I didn't notice before.

Now the CI have failed and I find that the problem is that simple_alias is missing in the [library-paddle] section of the cofig.ini file. Can I modify this file?

-----------------
simple_alias = xx
fluent_alias = xx
alias = xx
reverse_alias = xx
Thanks, @tngt for all the hard work! This seems perfectly organized, as is also reflected in the reduced diff. Yes please go ahead with adding all the aliases to `config.ini`.

> @tngt I've made a few more suggestions on the PR. Thanks again for working on this.

Thank you for your suggestion. When I load jupyter notebook, it will automatically generate a lot of 'none' characters. I will solve it as soon as possible and PR again. Thank you for your patience and guidance.

Hello @AnirudhDagar ,sorry to bother you, I see that CI shows "name nn is not defined", I found that the import is missing in paddle.py, I have run d2lbook build lib, but the following code is not automatically generated:

Here is the code in torch.py, we are missing the same part:

-------

import torchvision
from PIL import Image
from torch import nn
from torch.nn import functional as F
from torch.utils import data
from torchvision import transforms

-------

But I can't modify the paddle.py file manually, how can I fix this?

Hi @tngt that's a good question. As mentioned in the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/d2l-ai/d2l-en/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md):

> If the saved functions require some packages to be imported, you can add them to chapter_preface/index.md under the respective framework tab and run d2lbook build lib. Now the import will also be reflected in the d2l library after running and the saved functions can access the imported lib.

In simple words you need to add the imports that you want to save in `paddle.py` file to `chapter_preface/index.md` so that they are included after automatic generation.

You can see my PR here for reference https://github.com/d2l-ai/d2l-zh/pull/1127/files. If you look closely, you'll see the changes made in `chapter_preface/index.md`.

Hi, the recent changes on master branch are incorporated into this pr, can you review this pr again? @astonzhang @cheungdaven

> Quick issue: https://github.com/d2l-ai/d2l-zh/blob/paddle/static/build.yml looks outdated, can you also sync the env from the master branch?

it seems that  when I add     `- d2l==0.17.5 ` to build.yml，the ci failed and there are conflicts here

> > Quick issue: https://github.com/d2l-ai/d2l-zh/blob/paddle/static/build.yml looks outdated, can you also sync the env from the master branch?
> > @cheungdaven PTAL
> 
> it seems that when I add `- d2l==0.17.5 ` to build.yml，the ci failed and there are conflicts here

d2l==0.17.5 does not contain paddle code while `..` means installing from source (containing d2l/paddle.py) on the paddle branch. Please copy d2l/mxnet.py, d2l/torch.py, and d2l/tensorflow.py from the 0.17.5 release source: https://github.com/d2l-ai/d2l-en/tree/v0.17.5/d2l  to paddle branch and keep `..` in build.yml. In this way, installing d2l from your source will include all the d2l==0.17.5 code, together with the `d2l/paddle.py`. We may consider uploading d2l==0.17.6 containing paddle implementation later.

> PS: I don't know why the request compare the oldest version and show the all changes. Should I fork the project again before I modify the new file?

Hi @zhuyuanxiang , you can try the following command on you current repo:

```
git fetch origin master
git rebase origin/master
git log  ## you should see your latest changes
```
Please see more details about "git fetch + git rebase" here: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/3357122/what-is-the-difference-between-git-pull-and-git-fetch-git-rebase

> PS: I don't know why the request compare the oldest version and show the all changes. Should I fork the project again before I modify the new file?

Try the following cmd:
## Step 0: commit all your change to your current git repo, and then check the official git name (mine is called "origin"):

git remote -v

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37914843/113808804-a4d0f180-971b-11eb-99ca-803cbc01c65b.png)

git fetch origin
```

## Step 2: clone a brand new "branch" as same as "origin/master":
```
git checkout -b new_branch origin/master
```
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37914843/113809009-1610a480-971c-11eb-8a97-2c9a13b1496b.png)

comments_data.body: @cheungdaven seems like paddle is not able to find CUDA device. Similar issue in #1103

what is the current Cuda version on the server? @AnirudhDagar 

> @cheungdaven seems like paddle is not able to find CUDA device. Similar issue in #1103
We've both CUDA 11.2 and CUDA 10.2.

> We've both CUDA 11.2 and CUDA 10.2.

hello，do you need a paddlepaddle engineer to solve the problem together?

> > We've both CUDA 11.2 and CUDA 10.2.
> 
> hello，do you need a paddlepaddle engineer to solve the problem together?

Hi @tngt , I am looking into this issue. Can we discuss this in the slack channel?

> > > We've both CUDA 11.2 and CUDA 10.2.
> > 
> > 
> > hello，do you need a paddlepaddle engineer to solve the problem together?
> 
> Hi @tngt , I am looking into this issue. Can we discuss this in the slack channel?

ok i'm online
@d2l-bot please rebuild!

Hi @tngt,

@cheungdaven and I looked into the issue. The problem here is that `d2lbook` [intelligently](https://github.com/d2l-ai/d2l-book/blob/d933bfa91ce03ab6111db648045a1169060f99b7/d2lbook/resource.py#L30) only wants to assign GPUs to the notebooks which really demand GPUs. So it has various patterns it looks for to see if the notebook needs GPU. For example a notebook like https://github.com/d2l-ai/d2l-zh/blob/master/chapter_preliminaries/calculus.md doesn't really require a GPU. But paddlepaddle when installed for CUDA will always try to run everything on GPUs. In this case when such a notebook is encountered for paddle and d2lbook doesn't make the CUDA DEVICES VISIBLE, then we end up with these CUDA errors.


There are a few possible solutions:

1. We change d2lbook to allow paddle to find GPUs for all the notebooks. This will solve the problem but may not be best in terms of resource usage in CI and parallelization of resources when building in CI.
2. We add `paddle.device.set_device('cpu')` after `import paddle` line, in all the notebooks where GPU is not required. This one is a better solution.

Ideal way should be (like it is with all other frameworks), that, if GPUs are not found, paddle should automatically run everything on CPU. Is that possible? For now @cheungdaven installed `paddlepaddle-gpu==2.2.2.post112` and with that it is not possible automatically.

cc @astonzhang

@tngt just give me a moment, I'm consolidating everything (will probably make changes to the d2lbook package) and will comment on the PRs with the steps ahead. Just wanted to let you know so that you can utilise your time in a better way. Thanks for being patient :))

Hi @tngt, sorry if I didn't make it clear after my review. Yes, now that we have fixed the CUDA issue within `d2lbook`, please continue with other chapters. They should be fine. I'll also do a cursory review of the other open PRs.

This is the expected workflow for raising the PR:
1. Add paddle support for a chapter by modifying the source markdown files and testing them locally.
2. Run `d2lbook build lib` (You may need to install it by `pip install git+https://github.com/d2l-ai/d2l-book`) to save all the functions marked with #@save in [`d2l/paddle.py`](https://github.com/d2l-ai/d2l-zh/blob/paddle/d2l/paddle.py). Before sending the PR, please also commit these lib changes in `paddle.py` file.

Feel free to follow the steps in https://github.com/d2l-ai/d2l-en/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md for a detailed d2l development workflow.

issues.title: Add sentiment analysis notebook
issues.body: Add sentiment analysis notebook using pretrained embedding and biLSTM.

comments_data.body: Let's just improve the style per our offline discussions. Thanks for the contributions!

This example could have been a lot simpler with the nlp package. I understand from offline discussion that you want to avoid using experimental features. If that's the case, all references to mxnet.contrib (including contrib.text) should be removed. If not, then it's much simpler to use the toolkit as was done in https://gluon-nlp.mxnet.io/examples/sentiment_analysis/sentiment_analysis.html.
We'll still use contrib.text by assuming that it is stable.
content in contrib package is by definition not stable in the sense that any API in that package can drop at any version.

I think it is fine to use the contrib.text version. The example is to illustrate the easy usage of gluon alone (without gluonnlp) to build sentiment analysis model, which is different from the purpose of sentiment analysis example in gluonnlp.

In comparison with implementing pre-trained embedding from scratch, I think using existing API is more reasonable. We might use gluonnlp but its chance of change is much higher than that of contrib.text.

@szha It really depends. 1) any version can be unstable. If the Gluonnlp is now in Gluon. It will be more stable. But now Gluonnlp is separate. So you see if it is finally in Gluon, we will need to change a lot. 2) the tutorial should be consistent. In the natural language processing session and the online video, we have already used the text api in contrib, it will be strange to the users that they have the book and find the api is different from what they have learned. 3) now the example is just using basics (vocab and embedding) of the text API, I believe this part can be stable. Why not we just use this, and not take the risk to change.

@cgraywang, given that: 
> 1) any version can be unstable. If the Gluonnlp is now in Gluon. It will be more stable.

The stability of a package depends only on how the version is managed, not on where it resides. Also, a released a version is a snapshot that no longer will change so the question of stability doesn't apply to a specific version.

> 2) the tutorial should be consistent.

Indeed. My impression is that the contrib.text API for MOOC was rushed, and the merge of it was a compromise under circumstances. Will elaborate more below.

> it will be strange to the users ... find the api is different from what they have learned

That's my concern exactly.  If we are making the same material into a book, I don't think including contrib API is better than including gluonnlp, especially if stability is the concern.
contrib.text was merged as a compromise for the need of weekly MOOC under tight deadline. contrib.text was expected to change, and [it even says so in the tutorial](https://github.com/mli/gluon-tutorials-zh/blob/master/chapter_natural-language-processing/pretrained-embedding.md#%E5%BA%94%E7%94%A8%E8%AF%8D%E5%90%91%E9%87%8F%E6%B1%82%E8%BF%91%E4%BC%BC%E8%AF%8D%E5%92%8C%E7%B1%BB%E6%AF%94%E8%AF%8D). Now that the maintained version resides in gluonnlp, naturally the references to contrib.text should be revisited.

> Why not we just use this, and not take the risk to change.

Because if we do so, we are teaching people to use an API that we don't have intention of maintaining.

@szha 

>> >> 1. any version can be unstable. If the Gluonnlp is now in Gluon. It will be more stable.

>> The stability of a package depends only on how the version is managed, not on where it resides. Also, a released a version is a snapshot that no longer will change so the question of stability doesn't apply to a specific version.

Yes, that is exactly what I mean. We should not write everything from scratch in this notebook, 
 this will drift the attention from the sentiment analysis itself. I think we both agree on this @astonzhang . Then we should use an more stable API in the tutorial. Are we going to maintain Gluonnlp for a long term run? Or it will eventually go into Gluon. I remember our plan is to merge into Gluon not maintain a separate Gluonnlp. In this case, contrib.text will be more stable compare to Gluonnlp for now, if we are not going to delete contrib.text.

For 
>> >> the tutorial should be consistent.

>> >> it will be strange to the users ... find the api is different from what they have learned

>> >> Why not we just use this, and not take the risk to change.

I think we have agreed on the consistency and minimization of the risk of chance of changing API.
sorry I can't make sense of the above.
Why would there be risk of changing API if this package depend on gluonnlp==0.2.0?

reading a couple of more times, it seems that the point that couldn't be agreed on is which API is more stable.

GluonNLP has the more stable version of the vocab and embedding API. Whether it will go into mxnet repo or not is hardly relevant.

contrib.text is in contrib package, which hosts only experimental packages and will no longer be maintained. We will likely clear out some old contrib package in the next major version of mxnet.

I think for users, they care more about implementing the sentiment analysis rather than getting to know about Gluonnlp in this notebook. All the basics are in the contrib, why we have to change to Gluonlp? How to use Gluonlp should not be mixed with the example. Besides, Gluonnlp will merge into Gluon, at that moment, what should we do?

gluonnlp is unlikely to be merged back within the year, and in between there will be many releases in mxnet, which means by the time gluonnlp becomes gluon.nlp. If you have the flexibility of changing the code to accommodate when contrib.text is deleted, I don’t see why the same flexibility couldn’t apply to gluonnlp.

Most of the dataset loading and parsing in this PR becomes unnecessary by integrating gluonnlp, because it has already been supported. If you insist on having users to read the boiler plates, feel free to proceed.

I agree that using gluonnlp saves code. However,

1. If we introduce gluonnlp in the book, users may "pip install gluonnlp", especially if they directly jump into this chapter. However, it is hard to guarantee that gluonnlp is always available in the future.
2. Since we are actively maintaining gluonnlp not contrib.text, the chance of breaking code is higher if we use gluonnlp in the book.

Besides, it is fine to use contrib package. For instance, the book "Hands on ML with Scikit learn and TF" uses 
```
from tensorflow.contrib.layers import fully_connected
```

Thank you for raising the concerns. By considering all the positive and negative factors, I still prefer using contrib at the moment.

1. the pip package of gluonnlp==0.2.0 will remain available for as long as pip exists. there's no need to delete the released packages even if gluonnlp eventually merges into mx.gluon.
2. do you really mean it that unmaintained code is more stable? we actively maintain mxnet and yet we don't dismiss the usage of symbol or ndarray besides gluon, do we?

I don't think any of the "negative factors" apply.

1. Why should we ask users to use gluonnlp==0.2.0 if in the end users cannot do "pip install gluonnlp"?  
2. We expect more code changes in gluonnlp than contrib.text, do we? I think that may increase chance of code break if we use gluonnlp.
